markdownRemark.html:
Our product is a backend-less desktop app. While it is made to serve a specific purpose for the NHS, we have designed its architecture to be modular. Developers can reuse these modules for various purposes involving SMS bots. In addition, the interaction of these modules is via custom but generalised interfaces and file formats. This allows other developers to implement other modules that can be interchanged frictionlessly. Thus, this allows for a developer community to emerge.

Architectural Overview

Our standalone app is split on 3 main components - UI, and two business logic entites.

All functionality is exposed by the business logic modules via a simplified interface. The UI codebase only visualises data received from these modules and calls the respective API methods to manage that data. This allows us to have a clean separation between functionality and UX.

Module vf-to-ubf is responsible for converting VoiceFlow design data into the “unified bot format” (to be introduced later). This is used when the user wants to create an SMS bot from a VoiceFlow file.

Module ubf-to-twilio works with bot designs in the “unified bot format”. It supports deploying these bots to an SMS backend, connecting them to phone numbers, and other operations relating to SMS deployment and testing. This implements the “ubf sms interface” (to be introduced later).

The business logic modules are designed to be self-contained and not depend on each other or the UI. They can be directly integrated in other software products to benefit developers.

The Unified Bot Format

During our previous proof of concepts LINK, we decided to convert VoiceFlow design data into a more convenient format we could work with. Since we were already doing format conversion we started thinking, what if we define a generalised bot design format instead? This brings the major benefit that we become way less reliant on VoiceFlow and their format, as well as opening the door to interfacing with other design environments. For example, Microsoft’s Bot Composer Framework could be an interesting expansion LINK.

From our research with other design platforms LINK, we had some experience with the capabilities and requirements of alternative platforms. So we came up with the design of the Unified Bot Format. It is a JSON format representing a graph of a conversation flow between multiple choice questions. It is explained further HERE.

UBF SMS Interface

While working on the UI we decided to define an abstracting functional interface. This would hide the complexity of the business logic as it is not within the responsibility of the UI to be aware of that. In addition, we were also aware that if the NHS were to deploy our system nation-wide, we would have to use a different SMS service to Twilio.

These factors led to the decision to create a common functional interface for an SMS backend. That interface would support creating SMS bots in Unified Bot Format, as well as managing the created bot instances and assigning phone numbers to them. We used our experience with alternative SMS platforms LINK to ensure that the interface generalises well. It is documented further HERE.

Why a Standalone Frontend?

Because we placed big emphasis in our research on reusing as much technology as possible - the pros and cons of which are elaborated in LINK - we do not have a backend. Our implementation of the UBF SMS Interface runs entirely in the frontend and stores all relevant data in Twilio servers. The application is standalone and does not store any local state. Anyone with access to that Twilio account can use our app to manage all bots uploaded to that account.

In short this allows us to:

  • Reduce the complexity enormously.
  • No risk of losing data locally.

What About The Business Logic?

The module vf-to-ubf implements the Unified Bot Format by converting VoiceFlow designs to it. Module ubf-to-twilio implements the UBF SMS Interface for the Twilio backend. Both of these entities are self-contained npm packages. More info HERE LINK and HERE LINK.

Up Next

In later posts we describe how we built the frontend LINK, the two business logic packages LINK, and summarise our contributions to the field LINK.
